DOCNAME: CASE OF HODE AND ABDI v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 14+8 - Prohibition of discrimination (Article 14 - Discrimination) (Article 8-1 - Respect for family life;Respect for home;Article 8 - Right to respect for private and family life)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant was born on CARDINAL DATE and currently lives in GPE . The second applicant was born on DATE and currently lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . The first applicant arrived in GPE on DATE . He claimed asylum and that claim was accepted in DATE . Prior to QUANTITY DATE , successful asylum seekers were granted Indefinite Leave to Remain in GPE along with refugee status . However , after DATE ORG were amended and refugees were granted an initial period of DATE Leave to Remain , following which they could apply for Indefinite Leave to Remain . Consequently , the first applicant was granted DATE to remain in GPE , to expire on DATE . At the same time , he was provided with ORG ( “ ORG ” ) , also to expire on DATE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the first applicant was introduced to the second applicant through a friend . In DATE he travelled to GPE to meet her and they married on DATE . They lived together in GPE until the first applicant returned to GPE on DATE .

CARDINAL . The second applicant applied for a visa to join the first applicant in GPE . Although the first applicant was a refugee , the applicants did not qualify for “ family reunion ” under LAW CARDINAL ( as amended ) ( “ the Immigration Rules ” ) because paragraph CARDINAL of ORG only applied to spouses who formed part of the refugee ’s family unit before he or she left the country of permanent residence . The second applicant therefore applied for leave to enter GPE under paragraph CARDINAL of ORG , as the spouse of a person present and settled in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Entry Clearance Officer refused the application on the ground that the first applicant , having only been granted DATE to Remain , was not a person present and settled in GPE for the purposes of paragraph CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant gave birth to a son . The first applicant was named as the father on the birth certificate .

CARDINAL . The second applicant appealed against the decision to refuse her application for leave to enter . The Immigration Judge accepted that the applicants were married and that the first applicant had sufficient funds to accommodate and maintain his wife and child . He also accepted that the refusal of entry clearance engaged the rights of both applicants under LAW . He dismissed the appeal , however , holding that the refusal of entry clearance would not interfere disproportionately with the second applicant ’s rights under LAW . In particular , he noted that she had never enjoyed her family life in GPE and there were no obstacles to prevent the first applicant from living in GPE other than that he could not speak LANGUAGE and would be unlikely to secure employment there .

CARDINAL . The second applicant applied for reconsideration of the decision . In a decision dated DATE , ORG refused to order reconsideration . On DATE ORG also dismissed the application for reconsideration .
CARDINAL . The first applicant ’s leave to remain in GPE expired on DATE . He was subsequently granted Indefinite Leave to Remain .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the Immigration Rules were amended to permit refugees to be joined in GPE by post - flight spouses during their initial period of leave to remain , provided certain other conditions were met .
CARDINAL . The second applicant has not re - applied for leave to enter GPE as the spouse of the first applicant .
CARDINAL . The second applicant gave birth to the applicants’ second child on DATE .
CARDINAL . At the relevant time paragraph CARDINAL of ORG contained the requirements for family reunion for refugees . It provided that :
“ The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter or remain in GPE as the spouse or civil partner of a refugee are that :
( i ) the applicant is married to or the civil partner of a person granted asylum in GPE ; and
( ii ) the marriage or civil partnership did not take place after the person granted asylum left the country of his former habitual residence in order to seek asylum ; and
( iii ) the applicant would not be excluded from protection by virtue of article CARDINALF of LAW and LAW relating to ORG if he were to seek asylum in his own right ; and
( iv ) each of the parties intends to live permanently with the other as his or her spouse or civil partner and the marriage is subsisting ; and
( v ) if seeking leave to enter , the applicant holds a valid GPE entry clearance for entry in this capacity . ”

CARDINAL . Consequently , at the relevant time a refugee could only be joined in GPE by a spouse pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL if the marriage took place before leaving the country of formal habitual residence .
CARDINAL . In DATE the Government introduced paragraph CARDINAL of ORG , which made family reunion available to post - flight family members of refugees . It provided that :

“ CARDINALL. The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter GPE as the spouse or civil partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in GPE as a refugee or beneficiary of humanitarian protection , are that :

( b ) the applicant provides an original LANGUAGE language test certificate in speaking and listening from an LANGUAGE language test provider approved by the Secretary of ORG for these purposes , which clearly shows the applicant ’s name and the qualification obtained ( which must meet or exceed level ACARDINAL of ORG ) unless :

CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of ORG is a general provision enabling persons present and settled in GPE to be joined by a spouse or civil partner if certain conditions are met . It provided that :

“ The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter GPE with a view to settlement as the spouse or civil partner of a person present and settled in GPE or who is on the same occasion being admitted for settlement are that :
( i ) ( a ) the applicant is married to or the civil partner of a person present and settled in GPE or who is on the same occasion being admitted for settlement ; or

( b)(i ) the applicant is married to or the civil partner of a person who has a right of abode in GPE or indefinite leave to enter or remain in GPE and is on the same occasion seeking admission to GPE for the purposes of settlement and the parties were married or formed a civil partnership DATE , since which time they have been living together outside GPE ; and

( b)(ii ) the applicant has sufficient knowledge of the LANGUAGE language and sufficient knowledge about life in GPE , unless he is under DATE or aged DATE or over at the time he makes his application ; and
( ii ) the parties to the marriage or civil partnership have met ; and
( iii ) each of the parties intends to live permanently with the other as his or her spouse or civil partner and the marriage or civil partnership is subsisting ; and
( iv ) there will be adequate accommodation for the parties and any dependants without recourse to public funds in accommodation which they own or occupy exclusively ; and
( v ) the parties will be able to maintain themselves and any dependants adequately without recourse to public funds ; and
( vi ) the applicant holds a valid GPE entry clearance for entry in this capacity . ”

CARDINAL . Prior to CARDINAL DATE , successful asylum seekers were given Indefinite Leave to Remain alongside refugee status . As they were “ persons present and settled in the GPE ” , post - flight spouses could join them provided the other requirements set down in paragraph CARDINAL of ORG were met . After DATE the rules were changed and refugees were instead granted an initial period of CARDINAL years’ leave to remain , although they could subsequently be granted Indefinite Leave to Remain . As a consequence of the change of the rules , for DATE refugees were not “ persons present and settled in the GPE ” and could not be joined by a post - flight spouse during this period even if all the other requirements of paragraph CARDINAL were met .

CARDINAL . Under LAW the spouses of other categories of person granted limited leave to enter GPE could accompany or join their spouse without any requirement that the marriage took place in the country of former habitual residence . Paragraph CARDINAL of ORG contained the requirements for entry to GPE as the spouse of a student or prospective student . It provided that :
“ The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter or remain in GPE as the spouse or civil partner of a student or a prospective student are that :
( i ) the applicant is married to or the civil partner of a person admitted to or allowed to remain in GPE under paragraphs CARDINAL or CARDINAL - CARDINALF ; and
( ii ) each of the parties intends to live with the other as his or her spouse or civil partner during the applicant ’s stay and the marriage or the civil partnership is subsisting ; and
( iii ) there will be adequate accommodation for the parties and any dependants without recourse to public funds ; and
( iv ) the parties will be able to maintain themselves and any dependants adequately without recourse to public funds ; and
( v ) the applicant does not intend to take employment except as permitted under paragraph CARDINAL below ; and
( vi ) the applicant intends to leave GPE at the end of any period of leave granted to him . ”
CARDINAL . Similarly , paragraph CARDINAL of ORG contained the requirements for entry to GPE of a person with leave to remain for the purpose of obtaining employment . It provided that :

“ The requirements to be met by a person seeking leave to enter GPE as the spouse or civil partner of a person with limited leave to enter or remain in GPE under paragraphs CARDINAL ( but not paragraphs CARDINALI-CARDINAL K ) are that :
( i ) the applicant is married to or a civil partner of a person with limited leave to enter GPE under paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ( but not paragraphs CARDINALI-CARDINAL K ) ; and
( ii ) each of the parties intends to live with the other as his or her spouse or civil partner during the applicant ’s stay and the marriage or civil partnership is subsisting ; and
( iii ) there will be adequate accommodation for the parties and any dependants without recourse to public funds in accommodation which they own or occupy exclusively ; and
( iv ) the parties will be able to maintain themselves and any dependants adequately without recourse to public funds ; and
( v ) the applicant does not intend to stay in GPE beyond any period of leave granted to his spouse ; and
( vi ) the applicant holds a valid GPE entry clearance for entry in this capacity . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE the case of A ( GPE ) v. the Secretary of ORG for ORG [ DATE ] EWCA Civ CARDINAL came before ORG . The appellant , an NORP national resident in GPE , was refused leave to join her husband , a refugee , in GPE because the marriage had taken place after he left his country of permanent residence . At the time of the application the appellant was heavily pregnant and there was evidence to suggest that her husband could not live in GPE . An Immigration Judge dismissed her appeal , which then went before ORG for reconsideration . The ORG was unable to identify any public interest being served by the omission from ORG of any provision for a refugee to bring a post - flight spouse to the country . However , it held that DATE could not be used to plug lacunae in LAW and , on the facts of the case , it was not engaged .

CARDINAL . NORP On appeal , ORG had no doubt that the interference with family life which would result from not allowing a husband and his heavily pregnant wife in a genuine and subsisting marriage to cohabit had consequences of such gravity as potentially to engage the operation of Article CARDINAL . It therefore fell to ORG to consider whether or not there was a public interest in refusing to grant the appellant leave to enter . As the Government had submitted its skeleton argument on the public interest point at a late stage , the court held that it was estopped from reopening the issue . Although it went on to allow the appellant ’s appeal against the refusal of entry clearance , it clearly stated that its decision could be of no authority if and when the issue arose again .

CARDINAL . DATE ORG ) had to consider the same question in FH ( ORG - flight spouses ) GPE [ DATE ] FAC . The appellant was an NORP national resident in GPE who was refused leave to join her husband , also an NORP national , who had been granted refugee status in GPE . It was not suggested that there was any other country where the appellant and sponsor could live together as husband and wife . An Immigration Judge refused her appeal . ORG allowed her appeal . It noted that with regard to the admission of post - flight spouses , refugees in GPE were in a particularly disadvantageous position compared to students , persons working in GPE , businessmen , artists and ministers of religion and so on . In particular , the ORG stated that :

“ ... the appellant ’s situation is by no means an unusual one , and it arises from provisions of the Rules for which there appears to be no justification . Unless there is some justification , of which we have not been made aware , of the Rules’ treatment of post - flight spouses , we think that the Secretary of ORG ought to give urgent attention to amending the Rules , by extending either paragraph CARDINAL or , ( perhaps preferably ) paragraph CARDINAL , so as to extend to the spouses of those with limited leave to remain as refugees . In the meantime , it seems to us that although a decision based on DATE does have to be an individual one in each case , it is most unlikely that the Secretary of ORG or an Entry Clearance Officer will be able to establish that it is proportionate to exclude from GPE the post - flight spouse of a refugee where the applicant meets all the requirements of paragraph CARDINAL save that relating to settlement . ”
CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of ORG provided that :

“ The leave of a person whose stay in GPE is subject to a time limit lapses on his going to a country or territory outside the common travel area if the leave was given for DATE or less or conferred by a visit visa . In other cases , leave lapses on the holder remaining outside GPE for a continuous period of DATE . A person whose leave has lapsed and who returns after a temporary absence abroad within DATE leave has no claim to admission as a returning resident . His application to re - enter GPE should be considered in the light of all the relevant circumstances . The same time limit and any conditions attached will normally be reimposed if he meets the requirements of these Rules , unless he is seeking admission in a different capacity from the one in which he was last given leave to enter or remain . ”
CARDINAL . Paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the Schedule to LAW provided that :

“ When a refugee has lawfully taken up residence in the territory of ORG , the responsibility for the issue of a new document , under the terms and conditions of LAW , shall be that of the competent authority of that territory , to which the refugee shall be entitled to apply .

Each Contracting State undertakes that the holder of a travel document issued by it in accordance with LAW of this Convention shall be readmitted to its territory at any time during the period of its validity . ”
